text:
S-X2
150. Calverley, Dorthea Irene (Mrs. H.C.)
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Mrs. H. L. Calaway
Present Address: 1307-12th Ave. Saskatoon, Sask.
Birthplace: Ashland, Wis., U.S.A.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS - I was a child housekeeper was Mrs. Charlotte Kirke. I am speaking from memory as child. What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? We came Oct. Aug. 1905.
   Where did you set up housekeeping? Ashland, Wis., U.S.A.
   Where had you been living before that? Ashland, Wis., U.S.A.
   For how many people did you prepare meals? 3 family and numerous bachelors.
   How far was it to your nearest store? 12 miles.
   How often could a visit be made to the store? Once a month walking!
   What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
   My grandmother died recently at age 86. We often talked about her memories. Early days which were dear until her death.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

   What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Purity...
   In what quantities did you buy it? 5-60 lbs at a time.
   What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $1.00
   How much did you use graham flour? 1 lb.
   Whole wheat flour? 1 lb.
   Was flour milled locally? Not until later. How far away? 12 miles. What year? About 1912.
   What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $1.00
   What other grain products did you use? Rye, buckwheat.
   Cornmeal? Yes. Whole Wheat? Yes. Farina? Yes.
   Other? Only prepared breakfast food. Remember was "fore" on pancakes, porridge and grape nuts. On 1909.
   Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes.
   How did you grind it? In a coffee mill.
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer all of these questions. The answers will be preserved as part of the permanent records of our Province.

Name: Mrs. H. O. Calverley
Address: 150. Calverley, Dorthea Irene (Mrs. H.C.)
Birthplace: B.C., Canada

1. INTERROGATORY QUESTIONS:

   a) How did you start housekeeping? What was your first housekeeping experience?
   b) Where had you been living before that?
   c) For how many people did you prepare meals?
   d) How far was it to your nearest store?
   e) How often could a visit be made to the store?
   f) What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
   g) What brand or white flour did you use in the early years?
   h) In what quantities did you buy it?
   i) What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour?
   j) How much did you use graham flour?
   k) Whole wheat flour?
   l) Was flour milled locally?
   m) What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats?
   n) What other grain products did you use?
   o) Cornmeal?
   p) Other?
   q) Did you grind your own wheat for porridge?
   r) How did you grind it?

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS:

   a) My grandmother died recently at age 86.
   b) My flour talked to me until ten days ago.
   c) Royal Homestead flour at a time.
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? ........................................... 10 lbs.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? ...........................................

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? ...........................................

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? ...........................................

At what price? ..........................................................................................

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? ...........................................

Did you make butter? ........................................... cheese? ...........................................

Did you make butter? ........................................... cheese? ...........................................

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? ...........................................

How did you get fresh meat? ...........................................

How often did you get fresh meat? ...........................................

How did you preserve meat? ...........................................

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? ...........................................

If so what year was it organized? ...........................................

Did you use game? ........................................... What kinds? ...........................................

For how long? ..........................................................................................

What part did fish play in the family diet? ...........................................

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? ...........................................

Kinds? .................................................................................................
3. **MEAT AND FISH**

What was your meat supply in early days? 

How did you get fresh meat? 

For how long? 

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? 

If so, what was it called? 

Did you use game? 

For how long? 

What part did fish play in the family diet? 

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? 

Kinds? 

4. **DAIRY PRODUCTS**

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? 

That was the price of butter? 

Did you make butter? 

What kind of cheese? 

5. **FRUIT AND VEGETABLES**

How did you get fresh vegetables in the early days? 

How often did you get fresh vegetables? 

How did you preserve vegetables? 

Was there a "vegetable ring" in your neighborhood? 

If so, what was it called? 

Did you use game? 

For how long? 

What part did vegetables play in the family diet? 

Was the vegetables fresh, cured, or canned? 

Kinds?
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Red Rose. At what price? .......
What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Ground. Price? .......
What other beverages were used? Lemonade, chocolate.

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping?
Could you get potatoes at the store? .............
If not, where from? .......
What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of? 1906-07
Potatoes, Cabbage, Carrots, Onions, Turnips, Beets, Grandmother had huge garden.
In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? .......
How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? .......
What weight? ....... How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? Both ways.
What was the price of prunes? .......
What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Yes.
Peas? Yes. Corn? Yes. Beans? No. Saskatoons? No.
Other foods? Wild gooseberries in 1908.
What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? Cotton in 1906.
What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1914.
What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1920.
Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Yes.
To what extent? Not a great deal. Just remember how.
Did you make your own vinegar? Occasionally.
Also soap!
6. **BEVERAGES**

   Just kind of tea did you buy?  
   Just kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground)  
   What year did you buy?  
   What other beverages did you buy?  
   In what quantities did you buy?  
   How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)?  
   What was the price of prunes?  
   What other dried fruits did you use in the artificial days? (apples, pears, apricots, prunes, raisins, currants, sultanas)

7. **FRUIT**

   Just kind of fruit did you buy?  
   What year did you buy?  
   In what quantities did you buy?  
   How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)?  
   What was the price of prunes?  
   What other dried fruits did you use in the artificial days? (apples, pears, apricots, prunes, raisins, currants, sultanas)

8. **PRESERVING**

   In the early years did you preserve food by drying?  
   Other foods?  
   What year did you first preserve fruit by canning?  
   That year did you first preserve vegetables by canning?  
   That year did you first preserve meat by canning?  
   Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying?  
   To what extent?  
   Did you make your own vinegar?  

   *not a good deal*  
   *occasionally*  
   *also apples!*

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? ... Royal dried yeast cakes
Did you make yeast for your own use? ... yes ... Using starter? ... yes ...
Using hops? ... no ... Salt rising? ... occasionally
Did you buy baking powder? ... not until 1929 ... Baking soda? ... yes ...
Cream of tartar? ... yes ... Did you make your own baking powder? ... yes ...

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? ... Royal dried yeast cake
Did you make yeast for your own use? ... yes
Using hops? ... no
Did you buy baking powder? ... Nat. Yeast 1949
Cream of tartar? ... yes
Did you make your own baking powder? ... yes
11. PLEASE FILL IN THE FOLLOWING TO THE BEST OF YOUR MEMORY:

| FOOD                        | Earliest date it appeared on the market | Approximate price at the time | How did it differ from the same product today? |
|-----------------------------|----------------------------------------|------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------|
| Canned salmon               | 1906                                   |                              |                                               |
| Canned sardines             | 1906                                   |                              |                                               |
| Other canned fish that appeared early - give names |                          |                              |                                               |

| Oranges                     | 1905                                   |                              |                                               |
| Cornflakes                  | 1905 before                            |                              | not in wax paper usually dry.                 |
| Other prepared breakfast cereals - give names |                          |                              |                                               |

| Minute tapioca              | in 1920                                |                              |                                               |

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) River for drinking, slough for rainwater, pond for irrigation.

How far was this water from your home? 3/4 miles.

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) Barrels.

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

We got a well in summer of 1909 moved in town in 1909. Waterworks started in Swift Current in 1910 or 11.
12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout)

How far was this water from your house?

How was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank)

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

we got a well in summer 1909 - first housework started in May banquet in 9/10/11
13. SOAPS

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Yes.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes. Wood ashes? No.

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Royal Crown, Armaly's.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Coal, wood, railway ties.

Where did you get your fuel? Gathered where a little coal about my first Monday. Hauled coal from town. 2½ miles.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) No.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) No.

By whom was your first cook stove made? Bought it from U.S.A.

What year was it purchased? 1905. Price?

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) Iron, and one aluminum pot, later enamel.

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) Earthen and wooden bowls.

When did you first see enamel ware?

Aluminum? We bought one "pressure style" pot from U.S.A. until we left 1905.
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Yes, wood ash.

What kinds of laundry soap did you use? Soap, wood ash.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Coal, wood, oil.

Where did you get your fuel? Coal yard, store, oil tank.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) Yes.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) No.

By whom was your first cook stove made? Bought it from Lusa.

What year was it purchased? 1905.

What types of utensils did you use? Iron, copper, tin, homemade.

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)

When did you first see enamel ware?

Aluminum? Are you using it now?
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

We used to take pails, scales or cups for our coal oil, sugar, molasses etc. There was no waterproof paper when I was a child. I took meat from 1949 on (striped). Wrapping I remember about 1914, not earlier.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast: oatmeal, eggs, bacon or salt pork, potatoes, butter, syrup and milk, coffee.

Lunch: potatoes, beef, carrots, cabbage or other vegetables (rarely eaten until I was in high school), stewed fruit, cookies, cake, often biscuits, supper about the same, or custard or pie.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? .......

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

1905 - Can't remember, but I remember grandmother making mince meat and fruit cake while I was still in a high chair. I remember her cutting up candied nuts she bought from us. These lasted until I was about 6-1/2 in 1909.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No, my grandparents came well provided with dried stuff galore - grandfather had planted 100 potatoes in June - and from the next spring on Grandmother Kerns supplied all the bachelors and many families with garden stuff and flowers. The poppies in the Mennonite reserves mostly came from seed they begged from grandma who had a square of them gathering at one time. Remember, I remember the quaintly clothed women in our garden exclaiming!
17. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? Give details. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

18. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation levels living on one or two locally grown foods? Give details. No, my grandparents had planted all the food we needed and we had a good garden.

19. How did you make do without electricity?

20. What was your favorite childhood memory?
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Grandma chopped her vegetables in an old wooden bowl I remember - and I was only a tot when it became my job. She often spoke of her horror of the "cow chips" and we never had toast until I was a big girl, except toasted on top, for someone else. She saw someone roast toasting over hot "cow chip coals" and that finished it. The "oven thermometer" was her hand. I never did master that! Many things had to be soaked.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

In 1907 after we moved into Swift Current, but we grew all our vegetables in the town garden until 1934.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

Remember chewing gum when I was 4. "Tutti Frutti" in a single "slab", and in 1909 "Violet chips" came in small purple tin boxes (I still have one!). I remember the hard candies - and at Xmas the long strips of candy "beads" in grocer's windows (in the dust!) There were flat candies (not very tasty!) with silly verses and mottoes on them. In 1909 there were "bull's eyes" huge white things with green rings on them and a cardamom seed in the centre. If you ever reached it because the teacher usually got it - either selling the lump.
20. Mention any interesting differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

21. Did you learn to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible.)

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed.)

"Jellies," "Fruit" in a large "slosh" and "Winter chips" (gum in small purple tin boxes [gosh have one]). I purchased the hard candies and at times the long shining "card" beads in grocers windows (the other) Five very flat cardios (not very tasty.) During really freezes and molasses for them in 1909 there were "full eyes" shape in what they call with good recipes on them and a can hammon seed in the centre. If you ever wanted it because the teacher obviously got it - under seeing the lump
in your chest - or it rolled on the floor out of your desk at school. We used to trade "sucko"!! Also there were huge black "jaw breakers" and bright red, hot cinnamon candies. Horsehore candy and licorice (the sour stuff!) was a standby. Remember peppermints in 1912. There were "chocolate drops" in bulk in 1905-06. There was popcorn with elaborate Japanese tops in in 1909, I remember, also jelly beans about that time, and candy-coated peanuts. I don't remember jujubes until about 1914. Baker's chocolate had a picture of two monkeys - one pulling the other's tail until it bled! Water softener was "Long Tom washing soda." - toilet soap was transparent, highly colored and scented by 1911 - either "Pears" - or "Granum." Up till 1914 and beyond "Fairy Soap" - It floats! Currants were almost as much sand as fruit - and raisins had to be seeded. I hated the sticky job! Grandma never had a cream separator she skimmed by hand as long as we were on the farm 1905 - 1907. She made butter in a dasher churn. Salt Valvap baked in the salt cellar! Mustard was homemade - and hot! Oysters frozen were cheap enough to serve every Sunday in winter when frozen. We made a huge root house on the farm for storage, and it was full. But grandmother often spoke of how "helpless" her neighbors were, and how she gave away many times as much as she used, because others couldn't make a garden grow."
Our dear chum - we visited on the floor
out by your feet! It also where we met
our dear friend, and thought about
him. We missed him so much.

1912 - Our new cottage was built in
June. We celebrated May 1st.

Water softener was bought in April.

1914 - We moved into our new home.

We made a huge root cellar.

We made a huge root cellar.

That year, the weather was very

We could not make a garden grow.
